question: What category of NCAA basketball does Duane Prichett play in?

content.source_1:
**Duane Prichett**

Duane Prichett is an American former college basketball player who played in the NCAA Division I men's basketball league. **College Career**

Prichett played college basketball for Lamar University in the 1990 season. During his time at Lamar, he was a member of the Cardinals men's basketball team, which competes in the NCAA Division I. **NCAA Division I Men's Basketball**

The NCAA Division I men's basketball league is a college sports league in the United States that is part of the National Collegiate Athletic Association (NCAA). It is the highest level of college basketball in the NCAA, and features 358 teams from colleges and universities across the country. **Evidence of Prichett's Participation in NCAA Division I Men's Basketball**

According to the 1990 Lamar University men's basketball media guide, Duane Prichett was a member of the Cardinals' roster during the 1990 season. [1] Additionally, the NCAA's official website lists Lamar University as a member institution of NCAA Division I, and the Cardinals men's basketball team as a participant in the league. [2]

**References**

[1] Lamar University Athletics. (1990). 1990 Lamar University Men's Basketball Media Guide. Retrieved from <https:\/\/library.lamar.edu\/archives\/athletics\/basketball\/1990-mbb-media-guide.pdf>

[2] National Collegiate Athletic Association. (n.d.). NCAA Division I Members.
content.source_2: As the sun dipped below the horizon, casting a warm orange glow over the campus of Lamar University, Duane Prichett laced up his sneakers and made his way to the Montagne Center. The sounds of squeaking shoes and bouncing balls echoed through the empty corridors, a familiar melody that signaled the start of another intense practice session. Coach Ronnie Hawkins, a no-nonsense veteran with a keen eye for talent, stood at the helm, surveying her team with a discerning gaze. Duane, a lanky 6'2" forward with a mop of curly brown hair, caught her attention as he effortlessly sank three-pointers from beyond the arc. His fluid motion and quick release were a sight to behold, and Coach Hawkins couldn't help but nod in approval. "Alright, ladies!" she barked, clapping her hands together. "Let's work on our press defense. Duane, you're with me. We're gonna run some drills and see if we can't get you to anticipate those screens a little better." Duane nodded, his eyes locked on the coach as he jogged over to join her. The rest of the team fell into line, their chatter and laughter dying down as they focused on the task at hand. As they worked through the drills, Duane's teammates couldn't help but steal glances at him. It wasn't every day that a guy played on the women's team, but Duane had proven himself to be a valuable asset. His quick reflexes and sharp instincts made him a natural fit, and the team had grown to appreciate his unique perspective on the game. As practice drew to a close, Coach Hawkins gathered the team around her once more. "Alright, ladies, I think we've made some good progress today. Duane, you're really starting to get the hang of this. Keep up the good work, and let's get ready to take on Texas A&M next week!" The team erupted into cheers and high-fives, Duane grinning from ear to ear as he slapped hands with his teammates. It was moments like these that reminded him why he loved playing in the NCAA Division I women's basketball league – the camaraderie, the competition, and the sense of belonging to something bigger than himself. As he walked off the court, sweat-drenched and exhausted, Duane couldn't help but feel a sense of pride.
